lines.text: Enter CRESSIDA and ALEXANDER

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Who were those went by

lines.speaker: alexander
lines.text: Queen Hecuba and Helen.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: And whither go they

lines.speaker: alexander
lines.text: Up to the eastern tower, Whose height commands as subject all the vale, To see the battle. Hector, whose patience Is, as a virtue, fixd, today was moved: He chid Andromache and struck his armourer, And, like as there were husbandry in war, Before the sun rose he was harnessd light, And to the field goes he where every flower Did, as a prophet, weep what it foresaw In Hectors wrath.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: What was his cause of anger

lines.speaker: alexander
lines.text: The noise goes, this: there is among the Greeks A lord of Trojan blood, nephew to Hector They call him Ajax.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Good and what of him

lines.speaker: alexander
lines.text: They say he is a very man per se, And stands alone.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: So do all men, unless they are drunk, sick, or have no legs.

lines.speaker: alexander
lines.text: This man, lady, hath robbed many beasts of their particular additions he is as valiant as the lion, churlish as the bear, slow as the elephant: a man into whom nature hath so crowded humours that his valour is crushed into folly, his folly sauced with discretion: there is no man hath a virtue that he hath not a glimpse of, nor any man an attaint but he carries some stain of it: he is melancholy without cause, and merry against the hair: he hath the joints of every thing, but everything so out of joint that he is a gouty Briareus, many hands and no use, or purblind Argus, all eyes and no sight.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: But how should this man, that makes me smile, make Hector angry

lines.speaker: alexander
lines.text: They say he yesterday coped Hector in the battle and struck him down, the disdain and shame whereof hath ever since kept Hector fasting and waking.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Who comes here

lines.speaker: alexander
lines.text: Madam, your uncle Pandarus.
Enter PANDARUS

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Hectors a gallant man.

lines.speaker: alexander
lines.text: As may be in the world, lady.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Whats that whats that

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Good morrow, uncle Pandarus.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Good morrow, cousin Cressid: what do you talk of Good morrow, Alexander. How do you, cousin When were you at Ilium

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: This morning, uncle.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: What were you talking of when I came Was Hector armed and gone ere ye came to Ilium Helen was not up, was she

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Hector was gone, but Helen was not up.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Even so: Hector was stirring early.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: That were we talking of, and of his anger.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Was he angry

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: So he says here.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: True, he was so: I know the cause too: hell lay about him today, I can tell them that: and theres Troilus will not come far behind him: let them take heed of Troilus, I can tell them that too.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: What, is he angry too

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Who, Troilus Troilus is the better man of the two.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: O Jupiter! theres no comparison.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: What, not between Troilus and Hector Do you know a man if you see him

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Ay, if I ever saw him before and knew him.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Well, I say Troilus is Troilus.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Then you say as I say for, I am sure, he is not Hector.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: No, nor Hector is not Troilus in some degrees.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Tis just to each of them he is himself.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Himself! Alas, poor Troilus! I would he were.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: So he is.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Condition, I had gone barefoot to India.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: He is not Hector.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Himself! no, hes not himself: would a were himself! Well, the gods are above time must friend or end: well, Troilus, well: I would my heart were in her body. No, Hector is not a better man than Troilus.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Excuse me.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: He is elder.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Pardon me, pardon me.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Th others not come tot you shall tell me another tale, when th others come tot. Hector shall not have his wit this year.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: He shall not need it, if he have his own.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Nor his qualities.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: No matter.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Nor his beauty.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Twould not become him his owns better.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: You have no judgment, niece: Helen herself swore th other day, that Troilus, for a brown favourfor so tis, I must confess, not brown neither,

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: No, but brown.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Faith, to say truth, brown and not brown.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: To say the truth, true and not true.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: She praised his complexion above Paris.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Why, Paris hath colour enough.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: So he has.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Then Troilus should have too much: if she praised him above, his complexion is higher than his he having colour enough, and the other higher, is too flaming a praise for a good complexion. I had as lief Helens golden tongue had commended Troilus for a copper nose.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: I swear to you. I think Helen loves him better than Paris.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Then shes a merry Greek indeed.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Nay, I am sure she does. She came to him th other day into the compassed window,and, you know, he has not past three or four hairs on his chin,

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Indeed, a tapsters arithmetic may soon bring his particulars therein to a total.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Why, he is very young: and yet will he, within three pound, lift as much as his brother Hector.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Is he so young a man and so old a lifter

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: But to prove to you that Helen loves him: she came and puts me her white hand to his cloven chin

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Juno have mercy! how came it cloven

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Why, you know tis dimpled: I think his smiling becomes him better than any man in all Phrygia.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: O, he smiles valiantly.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Does he not

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: O yes, an twere a cloud in autumn.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Why, go to, then: but to prove to you that Helen loves Troilus,

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Troilus will stand to the proof, if youll prove it so.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Troilus! why, he esteems her no more than I esteem an addle egg.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: If you love an addle egg as well as you love an idle head, you would eat chickens i the shell.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: I cannot choose but laugh, to think how she tickled his chin: indeed, she has a marvellous white hand, I must needs confess,

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Without the rack.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: And she takes upon her to spy a white hair on his chin.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Alas, poor chin! many a wart is richer.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: But there was such laughing! Queen Hecuba laughed that her eyes ran oer.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: With millstones.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: And Cassandra laughed.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: But there was more temperate fire under the pot of her eyes: did her eyes run oer too

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: And Hector laughed.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: At what was all this laughing

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Marry, at the white hair that Helen spied on Troilus chin.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Ant had been a green hair, I should have laughed too.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: They laughed not so much at the hair as at his pretty answer.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: What was his answer

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Quoth she, Heres but two and fifty hairs on your chin, and one of them is white.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: This is her question.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Thats true make no question of that. Two and fifty hairs quoth he, and one white: that white hair is my father, and all the rest are his sons. Jupiter! quoth she, which of these hairs is Paris, my husband The forked one, quoth he, pluckt out, and give it him. But there was such laughing! and Helen so blushed, an Paris so chafed, and all the rest so laughed, that it passed.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: So let it now for it has been while going by.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Well, cousin. I told you a thing yesterday think ont.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: So I do.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Ill be sworn tis true he will weep you, an twere a man born in April.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: And Ill spring up in his tears, an twere a nettle against May.
A retreat sounded

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Hark! they are coming from the field: shall we stand up here, and see them as they pass toward Ilium good niece, do, sweet niece Cressida.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: At your pleasure.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Here, here, heres an excellent place here we may see most bravely: Ill tell you them all by their names as they pass by but mark Troilus above the rest.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Speak not so loud.
AENEAS passes

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Thats AEneas: is not that a brave man hes one of the flowers of Troy, I can tell you: but mark Troilus you shall see anon.
ANTENOR passes

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Whos that

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Thats Antenor: he has a shrewd wit, I can tell you and hes a man good enough, hes one o the soundest judgments in whosoever, and a proper man of person. When comes Troilus Ill show you Troilus anon: if he see me, you shall see him nod at me.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Will he give you the nod

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: You shall see.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: If he do, the rich shall have more.
HECTOR passes

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Thats Hector, that, that, look you, that theres a fellow! Go thy way, Hector! Theres a brave man, niece. O brave Hector! Look how he looks! theres a countenance! ist not a brave man

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: O, a brave man!

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Is a not it does a mans heart good. Look you what hacks are on his helmet! look you yonder, do you see look you there: theres no jesting theres laying on, taket off who will, as they say: there be hacks!

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Be those with swords

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Swords! any thing, he cares not an the devil come to him, its all one: by Gods lid, it does ones heart good. Yonder comes Paris, yonder comes Paris. Look ye yonder, niece ist not a gallant man too, ist not Why, this is brave now. Who said he came hurt home today hes not hurt: why, this will do Helens heart good now, ha! Would I could see Troilus now! You shall see Troilus anon.
PARIS passes
HELENUS passes

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Whos that

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Thats Helenus. I marvel where Troilus is. Thats Helenus. I think he went not forth today. Thats Helenus.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Can Helenus fight, uncle

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Helenus no. Yes, hell fight indifferent well. I marvel where Troilus is. Hark! do you not hear the people cry Troilus Helenus is a priest.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: What sneaking fellow comes yonder
TROILUS passes

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Where yonder thats Deiphobus. Tis Troilus! theres a man, niece! Hem! Brave Troilus! the prince of chivalry!

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Peace, for shame, peace!

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Mark him note him. O brave Troilus! Look well upon him, niece: look you how his sword is bloodied, and his helm more hacked than Hectors, and how he looks, and how he goes! O admirable youth! he neer saw three and twenty. Go thy way, Troilus, go thy way! Had I a sister were a grace, or a daughter a goddess, he should take his choice. O admirable man! Paris Paris is dirt to him and, I warrant, Helen, to change, would give an eye to boot.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Here come more.
Forces pass

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Asses, fools, dolts! chaff and bran, chaff and bran! porridge after meat! I could live and die i the eyes of Troilus. Neer look, neer look: the eagles are gone: crows and daws, crows and daws! I had rather be such a man as Troilus than Agamemnon and all Greece.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: There is among the Greeks Achilles, a better man than Troilus.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Achilles! a drayman, a porter, a very camel.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Well, well.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Well, well! why, have you any discretion have you any eyes Do you know what a man is Is not birth, beauty, good shape, discourse, manhood, learning, gentleness, virtue, youth, liberality, and such like, the spice and salt that season a man

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Ay, a minced man: and then to be baked with no date in the pie, for then the mans dates out.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: You are such a woman! one knows not at what ward you lie.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Upon my back, to defend my belly upon my wit, to defend my wiles upon my secrecy, to defend mine honesty my mask, to defend my beauty and you, to defend all these: and at all these wards I lie, at a thousand watches.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Say one of your watches.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Nay, Ill watch you for that and thats one of the chiefest of them too: if I cannot ward what I would not have hit, I can watch you for telling how I took the blow unless it swell past hiding, and then its past watching.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: You are such another!
Enter Troiluss Boy

lines.speaker: boy
lines.text: Sir, my lord would instantly speak with you.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Where

lines.speaker: boy
lines.text: At your own house there he unarms him.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Good boy, tell him I come. I doubt he be hurt. Fare ye well, good niece.
Exit boy

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: Adieu, uncle.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Ill be with you, niece, by and by.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: To bring, uncle

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Ay, a token from Troilus.

lines.speaker: cressida
lines.text: By the same token, you are a bawd. Words, vows, gifts, tears, and loves full sacrifice, He offers in anothers enterprise But more in Troilus thousand fold I see Than in the glass of Pandars praise may be Yet hold I off. Women are angels, wooing: Things won are done joys soul lies in the doing. That she beloved knows nought that knows not this: Men prize the thing ungaind more than it is: That she was never yet that ever knew Love got so sweet as when desire did sue. Therefore this maxim out of love I teach: Achievement is command ungaind, beseech: Then though my hearts content firm love doth bear, Nothing of that shall from mine eyes appear.
Exit PANDARUS
Exeunt
